primarySources.description: David's rise and flight from Saul

description: David, whose name means 'Beloved,' is the greatest king of Israel and the founder of the royal dynasty through which the Messiah would come. Anointed by Samuel while still a shepherd boy in Bethlehem, David rose from slaying Goliath to uniting Israel and establishing Jerusalem as the holy city. God made an unconditional covenant with David (2 Samuel 7) promising that his throne would be established forever - a promise Matthew's Gospel identifies as fulfilled in Jesus Christ. Matthew opens with 'Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham' (1:1), and emphasizes Jesus' Davidic lineage throughout. Jesus is called 'Son of David' more times in Matthew than any other Gospel. The blind men cry out 'Son of David, have mercy on us' (Matthew 9:27, 20:30-31). Jesus enters Jerusalem as the Davidic king on a donkey (Matthew 21:9). David the shepherd-king prefigures Christ the Good Shepherd who lays down his life for the sheep.

petrinePerspective.description: Peter's use of David's prophetic Psalms to prove Christ's resurrection and exaltation

pentecostSermon.context: At Pentecost, Peter quoted two of David's psalms to prove that Jesus had risen and was exalted to God's right hand

psalm16Application.quotation: For David speaketh concerning him, I foresaw the Lord always before my face, for he is on my right hand, that I should not be moved: Therefore did my heart rejoice, and my tongue was glad; moreover also my flesh shall rest in hope: Because thou wilt not leave my soul in hell, neither wilt thou suffer thine Holy One to see corruption. (Acts 2:25-27)
psalm16Application.interpretation: Peter argued that David could not have been speaking of himself, since David died and his tomb remained. Therefore David, being a prophet, was speaking of Christ's resurrection (Acts 2:29-31).

psalm110Application.quotation: For David is not ascended into the heavens: but he saith himself, The LORD said unto my Lord, Sit thou on my right hand, Until I make thy foes thy footstool. (Acts 2:34-35)
psalm110Application.interpretation: Peter proved that David foresaw the Messiah's exaltation to God's right hand - Jesus is both Lord and Christ (Acts 2:36).

petrinePerspective.davidAsProhet: Peter explicitly identifies David as a prophet who foreknew the resurrection (Acts 2:30)
petrinePerspective.conclusion: Let all the house of Israel know assuredly, that God hath made that same Jesus, whom ye have crucified, both Lord and Christ (Acts 2:36)
